text: yeah hi everyone Rhapsody ooh Tano here
the internet's busiest music nerd and
it's time for a review of this new
George Clanton album rapaya singer
songwriter producer multimedia artist
and labelhead Mr George Clanton he's
been making music for a long time now
but it's been about five years since he
really broke out and made a name for
himself with the 2018 record slide a
vapor and chill wave adjacent pop album
that was just drowning in euphoric
Nostalgia especially 90s Nostalgia which
continues to be a deep infatuation point
for George whether he is doing a
crossover collab with 311's Nick Hexum
or dropping a new slo-mo hazy
alternative dance single with vintage
beat loops and thick psychedelic almost
shoegazy synth layers being a child of
the 90s A lot of the stuff George makes
sounds like a distant memory for my past
given he's just a few years younger than
me I'm sure it feels that way for him
too it's something he's clearly pretty
devoted to so I'm not surprised with
this new LP that he's still hanging in
roughly the same place stylistically and
aesthetically this time with a trim and
Punchy tracklist as well as some slight
improvements on the production end for
one I think George has gotten better at
giving his vocals the shine they deserve
plus the synthwalls he builds on this
record just feel a lot more colorful
combine that with the heavy use of
effects he brings to the table it leads
to some really mountainous and anthemic
tunes namely the lead single off of this
thing
I've been young with its glistening
piano chords that are matched with these
cycling hip-hop infused pop beats riding
a meditative Loop George fills up the
extra space with lots of shiny synth
touches and some boyish lead vocals as
well that sound like a shine Michael
Jackson or maybe a b-level member of a
boy band from the 2000s that is until he
hits us on the chorus with these chorus
first expanded just blaring lead vocals
the instrumental at this point in the
track gets massive too George just
continues to have a knack for crafting
these gigantic soundgasms Plus in this
track we have very relatable lyrics
about growing old but not necessarily
growing up it's a great single and
there's more to be had through the
record like the other a single off of
this thing justify your life which also
scratches an ecstatic and nostalgic itch
with a lot of lyrics stealing in life
and existentialism my least favorite
single from this thing has to be Vapor
King Sub real Mostly because it sounds
like two kind of decent groovy psych
dance motifs that maybe if they were
worked on could have been developed into
full songs but rather than that they
sort of just do a surprise switch off in
between the two of them at the midpoint
of the song and that's just that it's a
two-parter with each respective part
sounding somewhat unfinished though I do
like how the vocal play and harmonies in
the latter section of the song sound
like something off of an Animal
Collective record maybe now I was afraid
that since Vapor King is not the most
well-developed song uh in the bunch that
with it being a single we be in for a
whole lot of underwritten tracks to
follow from here but no there are
actually other well-focused and groomed
uh bangers throughout the project be it
the opener everything that I want where
George sings passionately over more
endless beat Loops about how he has
everything that he could need or want
except you the refrains of no one no one
no one but you are pretty sticky Plus on
the hook you have this immense Rush of
synths that is just so damn crushing
it's like a tsunami uh pummeling a small
sleepy Seaside town it's just genuinely
good pop songwriting with great textural
play the tone of the writing changes on
the track punching down where George is
definitely punching throwing Subs at
someone who he says is a acting like
such a punk that he had to write a song
about it singing further into the song
Don't you wish you were dead music
sounds so good that it gets stuck inside
you the vitriol on the track uh the
music quality Flex though is real the
hooks do hit as well as The Groovy synth
sequences and thick Bass the following
you hold the can I found it goes into
even more Blissful territory the pacing
on this one is pretty slow this song is
going nowhere fast really in no rush and
I think that's because this track is
more of an attempt by George to come
through with more of a chill Vibe than a
formal and Punchy song it's not my
favorite here but it is nice while it's
on I suppose then the existentialism
comes back on this record with a rage on
[ __ ] up my life with its massively
distorted lead vocals Punchy break beats
this one's got a serious pulse to it and
sees George making peace with his own
unhealthy obsessions Hang-Ups and um
self-destruction in a way but then we
have a bit of a narrative switch on the
title track which sees George wanting
more out of life other than maybe just
this kind of infatuation with things
that have happened in the past now
musically and aesthetically speaking
I'll say I don't think this track adds
all that much to the record the chord
progression is a little weird the tune
isn't that strong either nor is it as
well structured as a majority of what's
here but still I think the song does
bring something pretty key to the record
in terms of concept at least and then
from here we have a pretty Grand closer
with for you I will which also features
Hachi fellow 90s music Nostalgia addict
and while there's not a lot to glean
from the track lyrically outside of some
deep regret over George feeling dumb
feeling so wrong and maybe being willing
to do anything to make up for it that
sense so much is clear the specifics
though not so much but at least the
instrumental here is the brightest and
most enveloping on the entire record
does give the album a nice finale and
while it is short I'll say overall I
think this is a pretty sick album has a
lot of creative overlap with the last
solo record George came out with but
with some fine tuning to the songwriting
and the instrumentals that I think
improve the overall experience and sound
which has got me feeling a light eight
